Author: sidhujag#3327
Content: @jl777 so notaries have access to blocks of every asset chain in entire tree they verify the header hash and then create a momom hash and stick it in every asset chain including the same hash rooted to kmd chain?

Author: jl777c#5810
Content: yes, notaries are all running KMD and the assetchains they are notarizing. the KMD instance maintains the MoMoM out of all the MoM hashes being notarized and sends back to the notarizer the MoMoM to use

Author: sidhujag#3327
Content: how are funds protected from double spends? its a new concept to me is it similar to eths merkle root for balances of plasma chains?

Author: sidhujag#3327
Content: ok so after block gets created kmd then sends the final momom hash to stick into next  assetchain block?

Author: jl777c#5810
Content: the MoMoM are being sent in via notarizations, and once notarized the block cant be reorged

Author: jl777c#5810
Content: if it cant be reorged, it cant be double spent

Author: sidhujag#3327
Content: the notaries can withhold?

Author: sidhujag#3327
Content: whats the recourse? being voted out? so what if aggregate value to withhold or to modify hash is greator than the bonded value and fees?

Author: sidhujag#3327
Content: is there BFT on the notarization layer

Author: jl777c#5810
Content: there needs to be a consensus on the current hashes

Author: jl777c#5810
Content: notarization uses a stochastic process that converges toward a majority consensus value

Author: sidhujag#3327
Content: are notaries chosen using a quorum or all of them are tasked every block?

Author: sidhujag#3327
Content: is 64 a magic number or dynamic grows?

Author: jl777c#5810
Content: annual election by KMD stake weight for 64 notaries

Author: sidhujag#3327
Content: so in any block the aggregate value should be below some amount to avoid notary from becoming bad actor?

Author: sidhujag#3327
Content: or does the consensus on the hashes take care of that thus the trust is distributed to 32+1 notaries?

Author: jl777c#5810
Content: there is no notarization unless there is consensus

Author: jl777c#5810
Content: only 13 nodes sign each notarization, but it is based on a 64 node consensus

Author: sidhujag#3327
Content: cool.. is there a fundamental num of asset chains where it gets hard for notaries to do their work? it seems notaries need to store all that data across all nodes and that can become an issue.. i guess plasma does fraud proofs instead and exit to parent chain

Author: jl777c#5810
Content: most assetchains are pretty small

Author: jl777c#5810
Content: we are working on ways to have multiple nodes per notary

Author: jl777c#5810
Content: but the notarization process has been made pretty efficient so hundred(s) of chains can be notarized on a node, if all the coins can be run

Author: sidhujag#3327
Content: each chain would be its own dapp no?

Author: sidhujag#3327
Content: like an identity chain for example

Author: jl777c#5810
Content: yes, the idea is that each chain localizes its activity to that chain alone

Author: jl777c#5810
Content: maybe a few related dapps are running on it, but the sharding is automatic, things are never combined into a single chain so we dont have the problem of needing to shard

Author: sidhujag#3327
Content: wait dapps are sharded across assetchains?

Author: jl777c#5810
Content: no

Author: jl777c#5810
Content: i mean the concept of sharding is not needed

Author: jl777c#5810
Content: the data is automatically already "sharded"

Author: sidhujag#3327
Content: oh ok yea

Author: sidhujag#3327
Content: same as plasma chain

Author: jl777c#5810
Content: sharding is only needed as everything is combined together and it needs to be split apart

Author: jl777c#5810
Content: with assetchains, nothing is combined together into a single chain

Author: jl777c#5810
Content: just the notarizations are sent to KMD

Author: jl777c#5810
Content: and a LOT of chains can be notarized to KMD

Author: sidhujag#3327
Content: right.. no its cool stuff im proud of you to follow through man.. ive had some more time to read what you guys did

Author: lukechilds#2707
Content:
Hey @jl777c currently implementing KMD interest claiming for Ledger, are you able to give me a solid breakdown of the interest/reward consensus rules.

As far as I'm aware it's based on the coinage of any UTXO over 10 KMD. The UTXO value is multiplied by coinage which is then mulitpleied by a specific number to result in the 5% apr.

I'm aware there was also a recent change that caps the interest amount once per month.

I'm assuming age is estimated approximately by number of blocks, so in pseudo code it would be something like:

```
const  interestPerBlock = <interest%earned every block>
let interestAmount = UTXOamount * coinage * interestPerBlock;
const interestAmount = Math.min(interestAmount, maxMonthlyInterest);
```

Is that more or less correct? I need to get this exactly correct to not violate network consensus rules. Feel free to point me to any docs if this is aleady documented in detail.

Cheers

Author: Alright#0419
Content: http://pad.supernet.org/rewards

Author: lukechilds#2707
Content: Perfect @Alright thanks

Author: lukechilds#2707
Content: a few Qs

Author: lukechilds#2707
Content: possibly noob Q

Author: lukechilds#2707
Content:
```
to be eligible it needs to be more than an hour old, have nLockTime in the tx set to be a valid timestamp
```
is nLockTime already set on all normal P2PKH transactions?

Author: lukechilds#2707
Content:
```
the times between the current block and the utxo's nLockTime are subtracted and divided by 60 to convert it to minutes
```
Does this mean the time is measured as "blocks since TX had 1 confirmation = 1 minute"

Author: lukechilds#2707
Content:
```
rewards once accrued doesnt go down as minutes since nLockTime never goes down, only up
```
can you expand on this statement?

Author: Alright#0419
Content: nlocktime needs to be set explicitly if you're creating the raw txs yourself

Author: lukechilds#2707
Content:
```
the rewards amount stops after one year
after one year, the rewards are still all there, the principal value is still there, it never goes away, even after 77 years
there is all sorts of misinformation, stuff like you have to transfer funds every year or you lose your funds, that is nonsense
```
slightly confused by this.
So if I have a 10 KMD UTXO that's 1 year old I get 5% interest.
If I have a 10 KMD that's 2 years old, I still only get 5% interest beacuse it's capped
What if I claim my interest after 1 year. Can I reclaim the next year to get anther 5%

Author: Alright#0419
Content: the daemon will do it for sendmany and sendtoaddress though

Author: Alright#0419
Content: that's outdated, it's 1 month now

Author: Alright#0419
Content: but like

Author: lukechilds#2707
Content: I believe it's only 1 month for UTXOs past block 1000000

Author: Alright#0419
Content: yes

Author: Alright#0419
Content: you can claim again after a month, hope that answers your question

Author: lukechilds#2707
Content: not quite, I need a 100% accurate spec for this so I can implement it perfectly, otherwise interest claims will get rejected from the network

Author: lukechilds#2707
Content: but you have been very helpful

Author: lukechilds#2707
Content: @jl777c are you able to provide this?

Author: lukechilds#2707
Content: I have been reading through the source and found `komodo_interestnew()` and `komodo_accrued_interest()` which look relevent but I could really do with a concrete specifiaction in writing

Author: jl777c#5810
Content: use komodo_interestnew()

Author: jl777c#5810
Content: the (chaintip->nTime - nLocktime) is the elapsed time

Author: jl777c#5810
Content: for specific utxo you can do gettxout and it prints "interest" field (I didnt change it for technical backward compatibility reasons)

Author: jl777c#5810
Content: needs to be >= 10 KMD

Author: jl777c#5810
Content: of course needs nLockTime set, else you cant calculate elapsed time

Author: jl777c#5810
Content: must be over an hour as 59 minutes are subtracted from elapsed time

Author: jl777c#5810
Content: komodo_interestnew() is about 10 lines of code

Author: ted#5473
Content:
The problem with the KMD solution is that the FLO community cannot participate in running a notary node because:
1. Voting in a notary node happens once a year and only a few of them are re-elected
2. Voting in a notary node requires voting with KMD

The FLO community should not be required to also buy and hold KMD to vote on a node to be able to have a small amount of control over the network. Anyone   can participate in the VBK network at any time
Unless I'm mistaken, GAME credits was the first coin to implement the dPoW algorithm, and they've only been using it for 2 or 3 months

Author: jl777c#5810
Content: to my knowledge, nobody in the KMD community has any significant BTC hashrate. we dont control the BTC network in anyway, yet we still utilize BTC security

Author: ted#5473
Content: yes,they said that.@jl777c

Content: why would they want to be controlling notary nodes? the idea is to not have to worry about such things

Content: they said Still in discussion with KMD devs

Content: they wanted duke to basically work for free

Author: jl777c#5810
Content: the design is that each chain takes care of making its own blocks. having one coin controlling another coin doesnt sound so good, so making that some sort of requirement is strange. if they need that then it is better they use a different solution

Author: jl777c#5810
Content: it is like not using bitcoin since bitcoin wont let you mine some percentage of blocks

Author: jl777c#5810
Content: oh wait, you could

Author: jl777c#5810
Content: just as they could mine KMD blocks, or become notaries. they just dont want to pay for it

Author: grewalsatinder#9653
Content:
@ted 
>The problem with the KMD solution is that the FLO community cannot participate in running a notary node because:
this logic incorrect.

Every assetchain in a project or every other 3rd party blockchain (hush, verushash, gamecredits, etc) don't need to participate in notary node elections.
But to pay for their assetchain notarisation. even a community member can donate for an yearly notarisation or a community fund can probably do that. aprox of 300 kmd per year I don't think is huge cost to save a blockchain worth multi thousand/million/billion against 51% attack.

Content:
if every new blockchain utilising dPoW notarisation required to have a notary node of their own, there probably would have need of 1000s of notary nodes. doesn't make sense.
only 64 notary nodes.
community elect with their token weight power
notaries don't hold the power to change or manipulate a blockchain
only thing these notaries can do is just send the transaction and do notarisation.

Author: Mylo#8306
Content:
```
The problem with the KMD solution is that the FLO community cannot participate in running a notary node because:
1. Voting in a notary node happens once a year and only a few of them are re-elected
```
Yes they can participate.  Get voted in.  This is part of any voting process.
```
2. Voting in a notary node requires voting with KMD
```
Voting in the elections is one part of the KMD ecosystem.  If you want to vote, be a part of it by getting KMD around that time of year.  The Vote coin gets airdroped to holders of KMD.  It is a community process.  How else can a community process be voted on?
```
The FLO community should not be required to also buy and hold KMD to vote on a node to be able to have a small amount of control over the network. 
```
Nobody is controlling anything.  Notary nodes don't control anything.  They notarize.  The voting process is how it is, if you think there is a better way, please submit details of a better way.

Author: Mylo#8306
Content: You actually don't need to hold any KMD.  Just run for elections and get votes from the KMD community - ultimately KMD community decides.
